Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: However, in many cases, subject is realized by a zero pronoun.

Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Non-agreement appears in the 3rd person; in constructio ad sensum: NP is in singular after numeral 2, verb appears in plural. Also the use with subject in 3rd plural and verb in 3rd singular is attested.

Name: Can finite verbs agree in number with a nominal object?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is no indication of object number in the objective conjugation in Kamas.

Name: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Occurs only in the case of inversion: Adj. N > N Adj.

Name: Is there non-agreement between an adnominal property word and the head noun?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is no agreement in case or number in the NP.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (S/A) marking?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: A genitive subject with a participle + LOC + possessive suffix is expected. Unfortunately, in all attested instances (possessive suffixes, personal pronouns of the 1st/2nd persons) the genitive form is identical to the nominative.

Name: Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (P) marking?
Do the characteristics of the object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Object marking depends on the givenness.

Name: Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does object marking depend on the verb conjugation form?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Zero marking occurs with the imperative, as in the other Samoyed languages.

Name: Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Is there grammatical marking of habituality?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: No special marker for habituality is attested.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of frequentativity?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The markers for frequentative are =l and =Vr.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Is there grammatical marking of the immediate future?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The most typical future tense marker is -LA. This does not, however, necessarily express immediate future.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of the pluperfect?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The converb -bīzA is used.

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is no aspect derivation of the negation verb.

Name: Can tense be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: It is marked in the future tense (as opposed to the imperative and conditional). Present and past tenses operate with the negation particle.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Converb construction with auxiliary nu- ‘stand’ (not entirely sure, however).

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of a desire or wish?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There are two possibilities: 1) verbs derived with the suffix -nzə; 2) construction with the participle in -NTə + auxiliary mo- ‘become’.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to irrealis?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Kamas has conditional mood. The marker of the conditional is -NTA...-ze; the first component is the participle in -NTA (-na ~ -ne after vowels, and -ta ~ -te ~ -da ~ -de after consonants), the second component is an enclitic morphem -ze which follows the personal ending.

Name: Are verbs marked with a non-indicative mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Not attested.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 3Sg?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: 3rd person imperative (jussive) is used.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 1Sg?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: 1st person imperative (hortative) is used.

Name: Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Not attested.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there a reflexive conjugation?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can the 3rd person plural verb form and impersonal (passive) verb form be encoded in the same way?
Are 2nd person singular verb forms commonly used with a generic meaning?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Not attested.

Name: Can an infinitival verb form be used in a directive function?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Modal infinitive clauses as in Russian are attested in late Kamas.

Name: Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be bare infinitive forms?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: In post-shift Kamas, the infinitive + lative ending was generalized in all uses (Klumpp 2016:54).

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the 3rd person singular forms of the present tense?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The variation between clauses with copula (ige ‘is’) and without is not understood; zero-copula predication, however, seems to be the default case (Klumpp 2016:66).

Name: Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the past tense?
Can locative constructions commonly occur without a copula?
Is the same coordinating conjunction commonly used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The conjunction ‘da’ is used.

Name: Does existential negation have a special negator?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The separate existential negation operator is the word ‘naga’.

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There are two standard negation constructions in complementary distribution: 1) particle negation in PRS, PST, and with non-finite clauses; 2) negation verb in FUT, COND, and IMP.

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Particle negation is used.

Name: Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is the caritive converb -žət (‘without x-ing’), elsewhere the standard negation particle is used.

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there non-finite forms specializing in the relativization of particular core participants, e.g., subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There are the following options: 1) Interaction of valency derivation and participle, e.g. amor-o-na ‘eaten’ (P) vs. amor-tə-na ‘having eaten’ (S/A); 2) Participle in -gA: only S/A; 3) Participle in -mA: only P/S.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can relativize all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some non-core participants?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Participle in -NTA is used. See also UT055.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least some non-core participants but cannot relativize all core participants?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negative marker?
Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject with possessive suffixes?
Are there participles that must agree with the nouns they modify in case and number in all contexts?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: In nominalization, participles need a dummy noun of general meaning, e.g., kuza ‘man’ (Klumpp 2016:54).

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: SOV is the basic word order. The reverse order, VO, can occur in imperative clauses, but also in verum focus context. There are also examples of imperative at the end of a clause.

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalizations in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalizations in the patient role be encoded like a direct object?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The accusative case is used.

Name: Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Attested only in late Kamas.

Name: Is there a bound superlative degree marker on property words?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Primary postpositions come without inflection; secondary postpositions, i.e. grammaticalized nouns with local semantics, are inflected for case and, possibly, also for person.

Name: Are there adpositions that show a tripartite system?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Secondary postpositions, i.e. grammaticalized nouns with local semantics, are inflected for case and, possibly, also for person.

Name: Is there case compounding?
Are there morphological cases only used with pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals greater than 1?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses indirect object/recipient/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses a terminative meaning?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the absence of a referent (abessive)?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Caritive -žət is rather a derivation, not a case.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses motion along or by a referent (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that expresses goal?
Is there a locative case that expresses location?
Is there a locative case that expresses source?
Is there case syncretism for goal and location marking?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Appears in possessive declension (lative-locative case).

Name: Is there case syncretism for location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Are there three or more sets of local cases?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniment (comitative)?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is an instrumental case with the ending -Śǝʔ.

Name: Is there a case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental), which is different from a case that expresses accompaniment (comitative) or other relations?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the result of a change of state (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a case that expresses a state of being (essive), which is different from a case that expresses the result of a change of state (translative) or other relations?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses equativity?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there (in addition to the basic declension) a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use the singular with the paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Are singular and plural possessee distinguished in the possessive declension?
Can a 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can a 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Is there a human vs. non-human distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The distinction is between animate vs. inanimate.

Name: Does 'who' commonly appear as a relative pronoun used for animates other than humans?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: No relative pronoun use is attested.

Name: Does 'who' commonly appear as a relative pronoun used for inanimates?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: No relative pronoun use is attested.

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used as a pronoun with a 3Sg human referent?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is no difference between the demonstrative pronoun and the 3rd person singular referent, the same word is used for both.

Name: Are there possessive suffixes, the position of which varies in relation to case/number suffixes?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The suffix order in the possessive declension is number suffix-case suffix-possessive suffix in all cases, except for the youngest case, the instrumental, which shows the opposite order (number suffix-possessive suffix-case suffix).

Name: Are case and number marked cumulatively across the paradigm?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The suffix order is always number suffix before case suffix.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relatives for relations other than siblings?
Is there an animacy distinction for both concepts: 'new/young' and 'old'?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The words dʼăktə ‘old (of persons)’, kuju ‘old (of things)’, ďēt ‘young’ and tăbdə ‘new’ are attested.

Name: Is there a distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' depending on whether reference is to weather or the temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length for consonants?
Is there contrastive length for vowels?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Vowel length appears secondarily, from contraction.

Name: Is there a contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there a contrast in the length of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Contraction of converb and aspectual auxiliary verb attratcs stress, e.g. kutla·ʔbi ‘caught’ (< kut-laʔ baʔ-bi ‘catching threw’); so while the converb -laʔ is unstressed, the aspectual morpheme -laʔ as in the example word is stressed.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: If the first syllable is light (open, short or reduced vowel), and a following syllable heavy (closed, long vowel), accent moves to the heavy syllable.

Name: Is there non-initial primary stress?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The (probably inherited) pattern of assigning prominency to the first syllable of a word by expiratory accent, e.g. ka·m.bi ‘went’, is challenged by two divergent patterns: 1) if the first syllable is light (open, short or reduced vowel), and a following syllable heavy (closed, long vowel) accent moves to the heavy syllable, e.g. su.ra·r.ga ‘asking’, a.mo·r.zit.tǝ ‘to eat’; 2) the Turkic pattern of assigning accent to the last syllable has been noticed by Castrén and Donner, not only in Turkish loans, but also in genuine words.

Name: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Vowel harmonic patterning of the reduced vowel includes also labiality.

Name: Are there closing diphthongs?
Are there opening diphthongs?
Is there a qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Kamas had eight full and two reduced vowels. The closed front vowel phonemes are /i/ and /ü/ (the latter is phonetically a rather central [ɯ]), the open front vowel phonemes are /e/ and /ö/ (the latter is phonetically often a delabialized [e̮]), and the reduced front vowel is /ĭ/, or /ə̈/ (the spelling as an [over]short ĭ is preferred here); an additional full front vowel phoneme would be /ɛ/, or /ä/. The back vowels mirror the front vowel system in terms of opening grades, labiality, and reducedness.

Name: Is there a high front rounded vowel /y/?
Is there a mid-high front rounded vowel /ø/?
Is there a high back unrounded vowel /ɯ ɨ/?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Appears in loanwords from Turkic and Russian.

Name: Is there a mid-high back unrounded vowel /ɤ ɘ/?
Is there a low back rounded vowel /ɒ/?
Is there a contrast between mid front vowels (/e/ or /ɛ/) and low front vowels (/æ/ or /a/)?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Notorious problem; if yes, it’s marginal.

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in the syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in the syllable coda?
Are there word-internal intervocalic clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized alveolar consonants?
Are there palatalized labial and velar consonants?
Is there a palatal stop?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is a free variation with the affricate ťś as an allophone. Appears also in Russian loanwords.

Name: Is there a palatal nasal /ɲ/?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: There is a convergence of palatal and palatalized nasal.

Name: Is there a palatal lateral /ʎ/?
Is there a velar nasal /ŋ/?
Is there an alveolar affricate /t͡s/?
Is there a non-alveolar affricate (e.g., /t͡ʃ/, /t͡ɕ/)?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The postalveolar affricate č appears only in Turkic and Russian loanwords.

Name: Is there a phonological contrast between an unvoiced alveolar sibilant /s/ and an unvoiced postalveolar sibilant /ʃ/?
Are there voiced plosives (e.g., /b g d/)?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: The palatal stop /ť/ has voiced allophones [ť] ~ [ď] which basically occur in free variation.

Name: Is there a glottal stop /ʔ/?
Is there a phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g., /k/ vs. /kʷ/)?
Is there a constraint on the word-initial alveolar trill /r/?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: r does not occur word-initally, however, it occurs in syllable onset word internally.

Name: Is there a laryngeal fricative /h/?
Is there a voiced velar fricative /ɣ/?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Appears as an allophone of [g].

Name: Is there a voiceless velar fricative /x/?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Appears in free variation with [k].

Name: Is there a voiced dental fricative /ð/?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Appears in free variation with [d].

Name: Is there a labio-velar approximant /w/?
out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC: Appears in free variation with [b].

Name: Is there a voiceless labiodental fricative /f/?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
